revised_title: Inhibition and Contraction of Antagonistic Muscles through Cortex Excitation
tldr: The authors conducted experiments on monkeys and cats to study the interaction between the cortex cerebri and muscle contractions. They discovered that stimulating specific areas of the cortex can cause inhibition and contraction of antagonistic muscles, a phenomenon they called "reciprocal innervation." This finding sheds light on how the brain controls muscle movements and could have implications for understanding neurological disorders.
